title: Typography for Certificate
content:
Hi All,

One of the students that works in my office asked for my help putting a certificate of appreciation together, and I wanted to get some good typophile input first. I've seen plenty of such certificates, but none that were actually thoughtfully put together.

So what kind of typography is appropriate for such a certificate?

Thanks for any thoughts on the matter.

-Casey
author: v-six

comments.content:
For the big type, something ornate and classy.

[Burgues Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20130502010835/http:/www.veer.com/partner/link.aspx?i=1048&c=4&p=products/typedetail.aspx?image=UMT0000267)  
 [Sloop](http://web.archive.org/web/20130502010835/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/font_bureau/sloop/)  
 [Sibyl](http://web.archive.org/web/20130502010835/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/sentinel/sibyl/?refby=typographica)  
 [Novia](http://web.archive.org/web/20130502010835/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/font_bureau/novia_ot/)  
 [P22 Zaner](http://web.archive.org/web/20130502010835/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ihof/p22-zaner/?refby=typographica)
Thanks Stephen, I'll see we have that would actually be considered classy.

What would be good for the small type in combination with the fonts suggested?

I know I am in my own little world, but its ok. They know me here

Here is a modest one that I made, for what it's worth:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130502010835im_/http:/typophile.com/files/award-owchar_5491.gif)
  
For this I used Canada Type's beautiful Bouwsma Text regular and Italic. The name is CT Mayfair. Since the name was so plain, I wanted something swashy.

I made the frame with the Illustrator frames app.
